content: yeah here's a great idea let's play a game where we go adventuring in the
frozen north won't that be a wonder of excitement to flex our creative muscles
and use our imaginations to imagine such a cold and barren wasteland hey guys
welcome back to black magic crafts it's really cold I don't know what the
temperature currently is it's probably like minus 35 degrees Celsius or
something like that I don't know I honestly stopped paying attention to the
weather forecast when last week it was all minus 40s and 50s me with this cold
weather my friends and I have decided to start playing Frost grave um you may
have seen my review video Tuesday where I talked about our first two game with
my first impressions needless to say I've started building
some stuff for frost grave now this week I actually had two different video
topics that I wanted to do and I couldn't decide which one would be best
part of me what part of me wanted to do a dollar store challenge and the other
part of me wanted to do big high detailed frost grave terrain boards or I
sculpt some really nice paver details and cast it and resin and make it really
fancy something that I've been wanting to do for D&D but could never justify
doing oh why can't you knee-deep snow is really tiring anyway I couldn't decide
between the two very very different subjects something really approachable
and easy that anyone can do or something really high detailed possibly not
something everyone wants to do but could be entertaining so I left it up to
patreon to decide and the folks on patreon they voted and they've decided
very clearly on the Frost great battle boards so I set to work making those
boards I wanted these things to be really nice-looking and I wanted to flex
my sculpting muscles and utilize molding and casting to duplicate those sculpts
so that's what I did this is gonna end up being a multi-part video because to
be honest it took me my entire allocated build time for the week just to get to
I'd say one third of the way down these boards so today that's what we're gonna
be doing I'm gonna be sculpting molding casting and remoulding and then later
we'll move on to mounting them onto some boards and painting them up I can't
remember where my houses which backyard is my pain I'm a little lost
guys if you don't hear from me by Tuesday send help let me say right out
the gate that I'm not making big snowy terrain boards for this game I already
have some snow battle boards and I'm not looking to make more of those with this
project Frost grave while set in a wintry climate is still set in a city I
also want to make boards that can be multi-use for D and D as well as for
staging photos of other minis and terrain so I wanted to make boards that
were brick lined city streets I may in the future create some boards that
transition from winter wilderness to these city streets but first it's
important to get this basic set completed because I wanted the bricks to
have sharp hard details that would be worth molding and casting and resin I
opted to sculpt my master from plasticine rather than foam foam is
great as a final use product but when making a mold in casting you want
something that you can sculpt the very sharp refined details into and
plasticine is a great option for that in my resin door video I
gave a piece of advice that was possibly problematic and I want to correct that
here I said that you could use anything to sculpt your master with and I was
informed later that this isn't entirely true some sculpting clays can actually
cause a problem with silicone which prevents it from fully curing plasticine
however or at least the craft smart brand plasticine that I have seems to
work just fine and I was comfortable using it for this as I had previously
used it while making two-part mold without any issue I worked the
plasticine until it became warm and soft then I rolled it out into a layer that
was about an eighth of an inch thick i textured the slab with aluminum foil and
as you can see it takes the texture really really well on some medium weight
chipboard I'd wrote some perfect three inch squares to act as a guide for
laying my bricks I cut strips of the plasticine in a few different widths
then slice those bricks and proceeded to start laying them out on the chipboard
this didn't work nearly as well as I had hoped
as the plasticine really stuck to my cutting board making it difficult to
remove without totally deforming the bricks after a bit of time and using
some sculpting Vaseline I was able to get the hang of it and eventually
transfer the bricks without much issue I decided to use a bit of hot glue to hold
the bricks in place as they wouldn't really stick to the chipboard without
applying so much pressure that it would cause them to deform or flatten out the
foil texture which I really didn't want to do eventually I got a complete tile
laid out my original plan was to make two 3x3 masters for more variation but
this stage had taken me longer than I expected so I opted to only make one
this was a bit of a mistake as a mint later I could only cast one 3x3 tile at
a time and that would actually make the overall process take a lot longer as a
result I should have just made two I used some foam core strips to create
barriers for my silicone mold by hot glueing them directly to the chipboard I
then took that chipboard base and hot glued it to a piece of MDF I wanted to
make sure there was no bend or warp in the master as this would carry through
to the resin castings later this made sure that the mold created was nice and
flat I then mixed up some of my muumuu 25 silicone to make the mold I covered
this process in more detail in my previous resin door video if you want to
go check that out and as I mentioned there the silicone that I have is
already well past its shelf life and starting to thicken up making it very
difficult to work with this is not normal for the material and fresh
silicone should mix and pour easily I sprayed the master and the mold with
mold release to ensure I could easily remove the mold once it cured before
pouring the majority of the silicone I used a brush to carefully make sure the
entire surface of the master had good coverage if you don't do this there's a
risk of trapping an air bubble and having a void or loss of detail in your
mold which obviously you don't want I did my best to shake out any air bubbles
but with the silicone being as thick as it was this was really hard to bring the
air bubbles to the surface the good news is it doesn't really matter too much I
also wasn't concerned about the mess I was making from the excess silicone as
it easily peels off surfaces once cured I actually use this excess spillage to
test when the silicone is ready to D mold which for amou 25 is about 75
minutes after the pour the mold thankfully came off really easily and
was a success although using the plasticine meant that my master kind of
fell apart in the process of de molding which in this case was fine I made sure
that after pouring my first resin copy I marked it as the first casting so that I
knew which copy had the highest detail for future molds
before pouring my resin I dust the mold
with baby powder this acts as a mold release without getting any grease on
the resin pieces it also provides a nice matte finish to the resin that makes
paint stick to it much better and importantly it helps preserve the life
of the mold which is degraded with each resin poorer using smooth-cast 326 ratio
and you can de mold in about 10 to 15 minutes when you pour resin without
using a pressure pot you end up with some air bubbles on the casting surface
but these are easily removed with a knife or dental pic or similar tool okay
guys here's the point in the video where I have to stop the post-production
voiceover and just talk to you in real time here because there's a bunch of
little things I want to cover when mixing resin it's really important that
you mix it thoroughly the first couple tiles that I poured I was mixing them in
these small little shot glass cups and one of these tiles took up basically a
full one of these which meant it was hard to mix it because it was so full
and such a little cup I didn't mix it vigorously enough and what happens is
you end up with these tiles that don't fully cure there's some of part a that
stays uncured or at least takes a very long time now these probably will
eventually cure maybe in several days but that's obviously not what you want
so use a bigger Cup or cut down a big one to the size that's good so you can
really mix it really well once you start feeling it warm a little bit then you
know to get the pour and pour it so that's the first thing I want to talk
about second thing is two safety precautions you get all these little air
bubbles on the tiles and you want to pick them off with a little knife or a
dental pick you need to wear safety glasses it's one of those things where
you don't think of it as a very dangerous task you know when you go use
a table saw of course you put on safety glasses but something this you might not
think about it thing is when you're picking these
little bubbles they fling in all sorts of different directions and it's only a
matter of time it's a matter of when not a matter of if one eventually hit you in
the eye and what you don't want is a sharp little tiny piece of resin
scratching your cornea don't so glasses the other thing is dusting these molds
with baby powder you don't really think too much about baby powder being
dangerous but when you're dusting and blowing repeatedly that's a lot of fine
dust in the air so you want to wear a mask but here's the real thing I want to
talk about my plan was to cast a bunch of these and glue them to MDF and make
12 by 12 boards and I wanted to make a 4 by 4 gaming area which means I would
need 16 12 by 12 boards and I started doing math here I've currently cast 16
of these tiles and that was yesterday afternoon and this morning it takes
about 15 minutes to cast each tile because there's 10-minute cure time
mixing D molding and you can't really do much else in between because it's a by
the time you're pulling one and cleaning one up there's a next one so one of
these takes about 15 minutes I really underestimated going into the project
how many of these I would need just for argument's sake here a quick quick math
so one 12 by 12 board needs 16 tiles and I want 16 12 by 12 boards so 16 times 16
that's 2 I need to make 256 of these and if they each take 15 minutes to make
that's three thousand eight hundred and forty minutes divided by sixty minutes
two hours that's 64 hours I would need to be casting these solid and that might
be fine to do on your own hobby time but with this being a channel which you
might not realize is each week I don't get a full week to build things I get to
maybe two and a half days and the rest is production and
all the other things about running a channel so it would take me weeks and
weeks to get through this so that's not gonna work the other issue is that this
mold one of these silicone molds you're only gonna get 30 maybe 40 pulls out of
it before the quality starts degrading every time you pull one of these it
damages it a bit the heat from the resin wears it out so I would also end up
needing to make about 10 of these in the process which would make it take even
longer but I still want these boards so I've resigned myself to maybe only doing
nine of them to make a 3x3 and they'll be border ones that are more like snow
or whatever there's still a lot of tiles so what I decided to do is I have enough
of these cast now to make a 12 by 12 I'm going to combine 16 of these onto a 12
by 12 board and I'm gonna pour a new mold I'm gonna make one big massive mold
so I can mold a cast a 12 by 12 tile in one go which will me not only need to
make 16 pours which will speed up the time and then I will only have to make
one mold I can get I think they're 16 out of one mold and the other nice thing
is that as you saw when I made this one my silicone is old it is well past its
prime and it's starting to thicken up and it's starting to fail I got to burn
through it so making this one big mold is going to allow me to use up some of
that crappy silicone and that's what I'm gonna do I'm gonna make a big mold this
will also allow me to place these nicely on a board and fill in the gap between
them so it's solid so that there won't be too many seams on the finished piece
only where you but one tile up to the next so let's do that so with the new
plan created I set to work making a 12 by 12 master I attached my 3x3 resin
tiles to a large sheet of quarter inch MDF using hot glue while assembling the
tiles I was careful to keep the outline of the square true as I wanted to have
those 12 by 12 boards fit together as nicely as possible
later I have a feeling that the still will won't work out perfectly and I'll
end up having to trim them with a table saw or something later but I want to
increase my chances of success as best I can
this proved to be more difficult than expected as my 3x3 tiles had variation
in them to mitigate some of this variation and create a straight and
square perimeter I used my rotary tool and a straight edge to clean up the
edges now a very serious word of caution here the dust created from sanding resin
is quite harmful if inhaled and it's very very important to wear a respirator
and thoroughly clean up any dust after in an ideal world this process would be
done in more of a contained area to avoid the dust getting into your work
area but I don't live in an ideal world I live in a real world with deadlines
and obligations so I was as cautious as I could be I wore a respirator and I did
a really good job cleaning up after with a shop vac once I was happy with my
layout I used some more of the plasticine to fill the gaps between the
MDF and the resin and to fill in the gaps between each tile my hope is that
by filling the seams in the tile I could make it look a little bit like grout and
when the large tiles were poured that these seams would become less noticeable
in hindsight if I knew I would end up going this route of a 12 by 12 master I
would have just created a 12 by 12 master with plasticine and then I would
have had a huge interlocking pattern instead of this 3x3 tiled pattern but
you know as they say if ifs and buts were candy and nuts well I'd have a
better looking for us grave tile to create the form of this mold I instead
used 1/2 inch XPS foam and glued it right to the MDF for this amount of
silicone I didn't trust thin foam core and didn't want to take any chances of a
mold blowing out I got to work mixing a huge batch of silicone and to be honest
I was really happy to be using up this old stuff in such a large quantity
it was at this point I found out that my little scale maxed out at a certain
point and just errored which meant I had to guess at the amount of Part B to mix
in needless to say this was a little stressful the silicone was already
problematic to work with and not getting your ratios right can cause curing
problems so I did the best I could at guessing on the ratio mixed it up poured
it in and hoped for the best this was a real leap of faith as cleaning out
uncured silicone from my master would have been a nightmare I'm a little bit
nervous feels like it's curing could use a
little bit more time it's a little bit sticky but the test pot seems to be

so in addition to hoping that this worked I'm hoping I can pull this mold
